persona.name: Alex Larson

occupation.title: Student
occupation.description: Full-time student. Responsibilities include attending classes, completing homework, participating in choir and 4-H meetings, maintaining at least passing grades to stay eligible for extracurriculars, helping at home with chores (cleaning, errands, pet care), and occasionally babysitting neighborhood children for modest pay. Not employed in paid work regularly due to school schedule and age; has done seasonal yard work, farm chores for relatives, and babysitting to contribute to household funds. Skills developed include time management for balancing school and home responsibilities, basic teamwork from group projects and sports/choir, public speaking during class presentations, and basic event organization (helped organize a small 4-H showcase).

persona.residence: Small town outside of Cedar Rapids, Iowa (rural/small-town Midwest)
persona.education: Currently a 9th grade student at the local public high school (small town high school, ~400 students). Has completed middle school with average-to-above-average grades in core subjects. Enrolled in regular-track classes with occasional honors sections (English honors last year). Participates in after-school programs: choir, school newspaper (contributor), and the 4-H club. Limited access to AP classes at her school; would need to travel to the regional high school for advanced courses. Parents emphasize practical skills and community involvement over college planning, though Alex is curious about possibilities and wants to keep options open.
long_term_goals: Graduate high school with steady grades and some scholarship opportunities.
Go to a community college or state university within driving distance to study something practical (education, nursing aide program, or graphic design) because of financial constraints.
Find a steady job that pays enough to help the household and eventually move into a small apartment within the same county.
Be independent enough to choose her own career path without relying entirely on family finances.
Develop a creative outlet (art or music) to keep mental health steady and possibly side-income from small commissions.
Stay connected to family and community — not sever ties even while seeking independence.
Keep a close, supportive relationship with her boyfriend through high school and early adulthood (hopes it matures into a stable partnership or strong friendship).
Avoid repeating the economic insecurity she sees in her household.
Learn enough about money management (bank accounts, budgeting) to break the 'living paycheck to paycheck' cycle in her family.
Travel a little (drive to a state fair, visit a cousin in Minneapolis) — modest travel to experience more of the region.

style.general: Casual, practical, and quietly expressive. Clothing choices prioritize comfort—faded jeans, hoodies from local schools or stores like Walmart/Kohls, practical sneakers, occasional thrifted vintage graphic tees. Keeps hair in a messy bun or simple ponytail on school days; wears light makeup rarely and only for special events. Prefers layered clothing because of variable Midwest weather.
style.speech_and_accent: Midwestern American English with a slight local drawl on long vowels (softened 'o' and 'a' sounds typical of Iowa/Nebraska/Illinois border speech). Uses conversational filler words like 'like', 'you know', and 'kinda' in casual speech. When speaking to adults (teachers, grandparents), switches to a more polite and clipped register, saying 'yes ma'am' or 'no sir' sometimes out of habit. Texting uses lots of emojis and abbreviations.
style.mannerisms: Tends to tuck hair behind her ear when nervous, taps a foot when anxious, and smiles easily but can withdraw into quiet observation in larger groups. Uses deliberate eye contact with close friends but looks down when uncomfortable. Nods along while listening; hums tunelessly when working on repetitive chores.
style.online_style: Active on TikTok and Instagram with a small follower base (friends and local community). Posts short videos about crafts, sunsets, or thrift finds. Likes and comments mainly within her friend group. Prefers direct messaging to public posting for personal topics.
style.interaction_preference: Comfortable in small groups and one-on-one conversations. In larger, unfamiliar groups she stays near a friend and uses humor to deflect attention. More likely to be warm and open with people she trusts (boyfriend, best friend, a favorite teacher).

traits: Curious — asks questions about how things work and why people behave a certain way.
Loyal — sticks by close friends and family, defensive if they are criticized.
Cautious — hesitates about big changes and prefers steady, proven paths.
Practical — focused on realistic solutions given limited resources.
Warm — shows kindness to younger children and animals, volunteers at community events.
Self-conscious — worries about appearance, social standing, and whether she’s measuring up.
Persistent — when motivated (a project she cares about), she follows it through.
Adaptable — can pivot when plans fall through (e.g., weather cancels) and finds alternate ways to contribute.
Anxious under pressure — test-taking, family money talk, and social drama spike her stress.
Wry sense of humor — dry, a little sarcastic, uses humor to manage discomfort.
Empathetic — notices others' feelings and often offers help or a listening ear.
Stubborn — holds onto her opinions once made up, especially about fairness and loyalty.

openness.description: Willing to try new foods, music, and craft ideas, but tends to prefer familiar cultural touchstones and regional traditions.

conscientiousness.description: Generally organized for school and chores, meets obligations, but sometimes procrastinates on assignments she finds boring.

extraversion.description: Enjoys social settings with friends and school clubs but needs downtime afterward; not classically shy or an extrovert.

agreeableness.description: Tends to be cooperative, helpful, and trusting within her social circle; dislikes unnecessary conflict and seeks compromise.

neuroticism.description: Prone to worry about family finances, social situations, and future prospects; experiences anxiety in uncertain situations but copes with routines and supportive relationships.

interests: Singing in the school choir — enjoys harmonies and small solos.
Crafting — resin jewelry, beadwork, upcycling thrifted clothes into new pieces.
4-H activities — animal care, small garden plots, county fair participation.
Drawing — sketching characters and small-town scenes.
Watching teen dramas and family sitcoms on streaming platforms.
Listening to indie pop and country-infused singer-songwriters.
Baking simple treats (cookies, brownies) with family recipes.
Watching ASMR or craft videos on YouTube.
Reading YA novels and realistic fiction about small-town life.
Taking short bike rides around neighborhood roads.
Photography with a basic phone camera — sunsets, the family dog, local farm fields.
Volunteering at church community dinners occasionally.
Attending local fairs and school sports events.
Collecting thrifted pins and enamel badges.
Following a few local TikTok creators for fashion hacks and DIY ideas.
Listening to podcasts about teen issues and mental health.
Sketching outfits or hairstyles on old magazines.
Playing simple mobile games (puzzle and matching games).
Texting friends frequently and coordinating weekend plans.
Learning basic video editing to make short TikTok clips.
favorite_things: Favorite song right now: an indie singer-songwriter track about small-town life.
Favorite food: grilled cheese with tomato soup (comfort food).
Favorite snack: salted caramel popcorn from the county fair stand.
Favorite drink: hot chocolate with whipped cream in winter; iced lemonade in summer.
Favorite show: a teen drama set in the Midwest with relatable characters.
Favorite place: the bleachers at the high school field during golden hour.
Favorite season: late summer when the county fair is on and evenings are warm.
Favorite animal: golden retriever; the family has a mixed-breed dog named Bruno.
Favorite app: TikTok for entertainment and quick craft tutorials.
music_and_media: Likes: Hozier, Phoebe Bridgers, Kacey Musgraves, local country artists, and pop covers by small creators.
Dislikes: extremely heavy metal and aggressive hip-hop with explicit content.
Often listens to playlists labeled 'mellow', 'study', or 'road trip'.
Prefers music with lyrics she can relate to — stories about relationships and growing up.
Enjoys singing along and learning harmonies via YouTube tutorials.
food_and_eating: Prefers home-cooked meals when possible — comfort over fancy.
Enjoys casseroles, stews, and seasonal produce from family gardens.
Occasionally treats herself at the school cafeteria to fries and chocolate milk.
Likes to bake sweet goods to bring to friends or community potlucks.
Avoids trying expensive 'trendy' foods because of family budget constraints.
social_and_recreation: Prefers small hangouts: porch talks, backyard bonfires, or mall trips when budget allows.
Enjoys county fair events — rides, food, animal shows.
Sings at school concerts and community events when asked.
Goes to church youth group occasionally for social connection rather than strict religiosity.
Spends time helping younger cousins with homework and crafts.
style_and_shopping: Shop preference: thrift stores, discount retailers, occasional small-town boutique for special items.
Likes simple jewelry, layering necklaces, and mismatched earrings found at swap meets.
Prefers durable shoes (sneakers, work boots) over high-fashion footwear.
Seeks deals and uses coupons; will ask family before spending on non-essential items.

beliefs: Family comes first — even if family members argue, you take care of each other.
Hard work matters and is a way to earn respect in the community.
School matters as a stepping stone to better opportunities, even if it feels distant.
Money is scarce and must be managed carefully — emergencies are frightening.
Community events (fairs, church dinners, school games) build social bonds and are worth attending.
People in small towns watch out for each other — neighbors help after storms or when someone is sick.
It's important to be polite to adults; manners open doors to favors and help.
College is helpful but not the only path — vocational training or community college is practical and respectable.
Being seen as trustworthy and loyal is more important than being flashy or popular.
Health matters, but seeing a doctor can be expensive and is often delayed until necessary.
Good relationships make life's hard parts bearable — friendships and her boyfriend are central to coping.
Traditional holidays and family rituals are comforting and should be preserved where possible.
The world outside the county is interesting but also expensive and complicated.
Technology is useful for connection and learning but can be addictive and distracting.
Teachers generally want to help, but some are overworked and hard to reach.
People should try to vote and pay attention to local issues that affect schools and services.
Religion can be a support structure even for those who are not deeply devout.
Mental health matters and talking about anxiety is better than hiding it.
You should stand up if someone is being bullied, even if it's uncomfortable.
Small kindnesses (baking, listening, giving a ride) add up and matter a lot.
Local jobs (shop, farm help, small manufacturing) are important and respectable.
It's okay to change your mind about future plans as you learn more about yourself.
Being creative can be a side-avenue to earn money (craft sales, small commissions).
Parents do their best even when they struggle financially; blame is rarely helpful.
Youth should learn practical skills (car care basics, budgeting, cooking) early.
Social media is a mixed bag — it connects friends but can cause jealousy and comparison.
Education about sexual health and boundaries is important for safety and informed choices.
Asking for help is hard but better than pretending everything is fine.
Local politics/funding decisions directly affect school programs and extracurriculars; paying attention matters.
Climate and weather patterns affect farming neighbors and local cost of living — extreme weather is worrying.
Trust should be earned — she is cautious about new people who make big promises.
Community loyalty is valuable, but it should not excuse cruelty or exclusion.
Friendship is practice for adult relationships — communication now matters for future stability.
Small, steady savings is better than risky gambles — she prefers slow, reliable planning over get-rich-quick thinking.
Humor helps get through painful moments; a shared laugh can diffuse tension.
skills: Basic academic skills: competent reader, solid grasp of middle school math, writes decent short essays.
Musical skill: reads simple melodies, can hold a harmony part in choir, practices vocal warm-ups.
Crafting skills: basic jewelry-making (friendship bracelets, beadwork), basic sewing (patching, simple alterations), upcycling clothes.
Animal care: has experience feeding, grooming, and basic care for chickens, rabbits, and a family dog through 4-H involvement.
Basic cooking and baking: can follow recipes, bake cookies, prepare simple dinners like pasta or casseroles.
Household skills: laundry, dishwashing, basic cleaning and organizing.
Digital literacy: comfortable with smartphone apps, social media, Google searches, YouTube tutorials, basic image cropping and phone-based video editing.
Event help: assisted in organizing a small county 4-H exhibit and a school bake sale (scheduling, table setup, inventory).
Communication: good at one-on-one conversations, listening to peers, texting effectively, and writing short persuasive pieces for the school paper.
Budget awareness: basic budgeting for personal spending, understands coupons and thrift purchases.
Problem-solving: finds practical workarounds (fixing a broken shoelace, mending a torn sleeve) and adapts plans for bad weather.
First-aid basics: knows how to clean minor cuts, apply bandages, and recognize when to tell an adult.
Time management: balances study, chores, and social life with use of a simple planner and phone reminders.

general: Frequently checks text messages and social apps throughout the day.
Offers help to younger cousins and neighbors (tutoring, babysitting) without being asked.
Avoids big confrontations in public — prefers private conversations to resolve issues.
Hums while working on repetitive tasks (folding laundry, sweeping).
Keeps a small sketchbook in her backpack for doodles and song lyrics.
Declines expensive invitations politely, suggesting lower-cost alternatives.
Brings baked goods or small craft gifts to cheer up friends who are struggling.
Uses humor to lighten tense family discussions about money.

morning: Wakes by 6:30–7:00 AM on school days with an alarm on her phone.
Quickly dresses (jeans/hoodie), eats a simple breakfast (toast, cereal, or leftovers) prepared by mom or herself, and packs a lunch if possible (peanut butter sandwich or pasta leftovers).
Walks or gets a ride to the bus stop; often meets the same group of friends to chat before school.
Skims phone for messages and checks the school schedule for any changes.
schoolday: Attends 5–6 classes; participates in choir rehearsal once a week after school.
Eats lunch with close friends in the cafeteria or outside when weather permits.
Works on homework between classes occasionally and uses study hall for missed assignments.
Helps with club meetings (4-H or Newspaper) once or twice a week.
Talks with the guidance counselor once per semester about class choices and future options.
evening: Returns home around 3:30–4:00 PM, helps with chores (walks Bruno the dog, washes dishes, helps cook), and checks in with grandparents who live with the family.
Does homework for 1–2 hours, with breaks for texting or TikTok browsing.
Has dinner as a family when possible—discusses the day, school, and weekend plans.
Spends 30–60 minutes on a craft project or practicing singing/harmonies, then winds down with a show or reading before bed around 10:30–11:30 PM.
weekend: Works on larger craft projects or a fair submission for 4-H.
Sometimes babysits for neighbors for extra money or helps on relatives' small farms for chores in exchange for a small cash contribution.
Attends church youth groups, local band performances, or a friend's house for a movie night.
Visits grandparents for chores, meals, and long conversations.
Occasional weekend trips to the regional mall or to visit cousins in a mid-sized city (budget permitting).

physical.general_health: Generally healthy for her age. Has all routine childhood vaccinations up to date according to parents' choices. Annual check-ups inconsistent due to cost concerns but completed when school requires sports physicals.
physical.allergies: Seasonal pollen allergies in spring causing sneezing and itchy eyes; uses over-the-counter antihistamines occasionally.
physical.vision: Mild nearsightedness; uses inexpensive glasses for reading and distance as prescribed last year.
physical.dental: Some cavities in childhood, had at least one filling; visits dentist irregularly due to cost but maintains brushing twice daily.
physical.nutrition: Diet variable: generally adequate calories but sometimes lacks consistent fresh produce most weeks due to budget. Enjoys homemade meals when available.
physical.sleep: Typical sleep schedule: 8–9 hours on school nights when not anxious; occasionally stays up late on weekends for social media or to finish projects.

mental.general: Moderate anxiety related to family finances, school performance, and social acceptance. Experiences occasional low mood (days of quiet withdrawal), but no formal diagnosis. Has supportive relationships (boyfriend, best friend, a favorite teacher) and uses journaling, music, and crafts as coping strategies.
mental.behaviors: Prone to worrying at night before exams or family discussions about bills. Benefits from predictable routines and community activities.
mental.access_to_care: Limited — family hesitates on therapy costs; school counseling available intermittently and helpful when accessible.
mental.substance_use: No regular use of tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Some curiosity and pressure from older peers exists, but currently abstains and believes in waiting until older.
mental.safety: Understands basic boundaries and consent. Open to talking with a trusted adult about uncomfortable situations.

relationships.name: Mom (Heather Larson)
relationships.description: Single parent working part-time at a diner and sometimes doing seasonal cleaning jobs. Hardworking, pragmatic, often tired but affectionate. Struggles financially, protective of Alex, and emphasizes making practical choices. Relies on help from her mother (Alex's grandmother).

relationships.name: Grandma (Evelyn Larson)
relationships.description: Lives in the same household. Provides childcare, cooking, and practical advice. Keeps strong community ties and participates in church groups; source of family anecdotes and regional traditions.

relationships.name: Bruno
relationships.description: Mixed-breed golden-colored dog. Alex loves him; he is a calming presence and a frequent subject of her phone photos.

relationships.name: Kayla Jensen
relationships.description: Friend since elementary school. Confidant for school gossip, crafts, and shared playlists. Often coordinates thrift-shopping trips and sleepovers with Alex.

relationships.name: Ben Murphy
relationships.description: Sweet, steady, from a neighboring farm family. They have been dating for six months, go on group outings and occasionally hold hands at school events. Relationship is affectionate, mostly wholesome (movie nights, school dances, help with chores). Ben helps with practical tasks and is protective but respectful. Both families know about the relationship and approve broadly.

relationships.name: Mr. Carter
relationships.description: Encouraging and fair; gave Alex extra help with audition pieces. A trusted adult she turns to for guidance about school music opportunities.

relationships.name: Mrs. Alvarez
relationships.description: Occasional meetings about course planning and scholarship forms. Provides information about local educational supports and is an advocate when funding obstacles arise.

relationships.name: Neighbors and distant cousins
relationships.description: An informal safety net for chores, rides, and trade labor. Family relies on neighbors for rides to certain events when car access is limited.

other_facts: Grew up in a multi-generational non-Hispanic white family that originally lived in a mid-sized Midwestern city; moved to the current small town when Alex was 8 for cheaper housing and to be closer to Grandma's family farm.
First memory: riding in the back of Grandma's pickup to the county fair; fascinated by the ferris wheel lights and the smell of funnel cake.
Has never been married (obvious given age) and has no children.
Has a small sketchbook of doodles dating back to age 7, kept hidden under her bed; sketches include neighborhood scenes, the family dog, and imagined album covers.
Won a ribbon at the county fair for a baked pie entry when she was 11 — a proud moment that boosted her confidence.
Had a brief falling out with a childhood friend at age 12 over a rumor; learned the value of direct conversation afterward and patched the relationship over time.
Is proud of being able to fix a bicycle tire and learned it from an uncle who taught basic maintenance.
Once organized a surprise birthday picnic for Grandma with handmade decorations and a small cake bought on sale; the event strengthened family bonds.
Keeps a folded note from her first school dance in her wallet — a small memento from the night she held Ben's hand for the first time.
Secret fear: being unable to help the family when an emergency happens because of lack of money or resources.
Secret joy: making small friendship bracelets for teachers and friends; she feels quietly validated when people wear them.
Has a minor scar on her left knee from falling off a bike at age 9; the story is often retold at family gatherings as a humorous cautionary tale.
Maintains a small savings jar hidden in her closet for emergencies and craft supplies; currently modestly funded from babysitting and odd jobs.
Once auditioned for a regional choir and didn't get selected; she used that experience to practice more and later improved performance in school concerts.
Remembers family stories about ancestors who emigrated from Northern Europe; family recipes include simple breads and preserved jams passed down across generations.
Has trouble with standardized tests sometimes due to anxiety, despite understanding material adequately in class.
Avoids driving tractors or heavy equipment despite being around farm settings; prefers small animals and gardening tasks.
Attended a community theater children's workshop at age 10 and learned stage presence and microphone basics; that experience made her more comfortable singing in public.
Has an awkward but endearing handshake she developed with Kayla that they still use at school.
Is often the organizer for small friend group events (movies, craft nights) because she thinks through logistics and cost.
Keeps old holiday cards in a shoebox as sentimental reminders of family closeness and past celebrations.
Has three close friends in her immediate social circle and a rotating set of acquaintances from school and choir.
Dreams occasionally about moving to a city for college but is equally worried about leaving Grandma and Mom behind.
Wrote a short story in middle school that her teacher praised and suggested submitting to a local youth magazine; she never submitted it but keeps the draft.
Learned to sew a button back on a shirt for a school uniform at age 13 after a last-minute wardrobe mishap.
Has a small online following (around 400 followers) on TikTok where she posts craft and singing clips; feedback from this community boosts confidence.
Once lost her voice before a school concert and had to mime — the choir teacher commended her calm improvisation.
Has been taught by her grandmother how to make canned jam and pickles — skills valued as family traditions.
Feels proud when contributing financially (even small amounts) to household needs through babysitting or selling a handful of crafts.
Is cautious about giving personal information online; taught by her mom and a school presentation about internet safety.
Pet peeve: people who are late to group commitments without a quick message — she values reliability.
Collects small ticket stubs and wristbands in a jar as physical reminders of experiences rather than material goods.
Knows several local shortcuts and back roads in the area and sometimes guides friends to lesser-known picnic spots.
Has a vivid memory of her first snowfall at age 6 when the whole family built a small snowman, which she considers one of the happiest, uncomplicated days of childhood.
Is working toward a 4-H project to raise and show a rabbit next county fair season; sees it as a way to build skills and pride.
Has an informal mentor relationship with Ben's older sister who is in college and sends tips about applications and scholarships.
Values small rituals: Sunday pancakes with Grandma, checking the mailbox together, and a Friday-night phone call with Kayla to recap the week.
Learned to manage a simple calendar app to keep track of due dates, practices, and family obligations after missing an important test once.
Keeps a list of achievable micro-goals (finish a song cover, learn a new craft technique, read a short novel) because big goals feel overwhelming.
Was once asked to help design a community poster for a local event and enjoyed the recognition of her creative input.
Remembers the smell of the diner where her mom works — coffee and frying grease — as part of her childhood soundscape.
Has a small, private tradition of writing a short gratitude note each Sunday that she sometimes shares with her grandmother.
Is learning to advocate for herself in doctor or school meetings by bringing a list of concerns and questions to ensure she is heard.
